In North American English, the term 'plurality', also called 'relative
majority' used in the context of voting, refers to the
largest number of votes to be received by any candidate (or any proposal in a
referendum). Robert, Henry M. "[http://www.rulesonline.com/rror--
04.htm#def:Plurality Introduction to Robert's Rules]" [[Robert's Rules of
Order|Robert's Rules of Order Revised]]. 4th ed. 1915. RulesOnline.com It
is contrasted with an absolute majority, or simple
majority, which is more than half of the votes. In other
words, in an election contested by more than two candidates, plurality occurs
when one candidate receives the most votes but not necessarily more than half
of the votes, while in a majority election a candidate wins if they receive
over half of the votes. When no candidate receives a majority in the first
round of voting, a two-round system or ranked voting system can be used to
choose a winner.

Systems allowing plurality election are more vulnerable to corruption using the
spoiler effect than systems which require a majority. Poundstone, William
(2008). Gaming the vote: why elections aren't fair (and what we can do about
it). Hill and Wang. ISBN 978-0-8090-4893-9.
